snippet: Using satellite technology, much of it smuggled in, activists are still communicating online during an Internet blackout that started Thursday, but the government is finding ways to listen.
abstract: Syrian rebels respond to nationwide Internet shutdown by turning to satellite technology to coordinate within country and to communicate with outside activists; for months, rebels fighting to overthrow Pres Bashar al-Assad have used Skype, peer-to-peer Internet communication system, to organize and talk to outside news organizations and activists.

byline.contributor: Liam Stack contributed reporting from New York; Hala Droubi from Dubai, United Arab Emirates; and Hwaida Saad from Beirut, Lebanon.

lead_paragraph: Using satellite technology, much of it smuggled in, activists are still communicating online during an Internet blackout that started Thursday, but the government is finding ways to listen.

headline.seo: Syria Rebels Find Skype Useful, but Dangers Lurk
headline.main: For Syria’s Rebel Movement, Skype Is a Useful and Increasingly Dangerous Tool
headline.print_headline: For Syria’s Rebel Movement, Skype Is a Useful and Increasingly Dangerous Tool
